Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2008 11:14AM hopefullady wrote: BlueMama,  I am currently facing that very decision, and it is not an easy one. I turned 51 in June.  I was diagnosed in May, lumpectomy and sentinel node biopsy on June 2nd, tumor 1 cm.  Clean margins and no node involvement.  Was ER/PR+   I had Mammosite radiation last week of June.  In July I had the Oncotype test which came back at 20.   The chance of recurrence for me was 13% with Tamoxifen for five years, and 6% if I have four rounds of chemo before the Tamoxifen.   My oncologist and the second opinion both recommend chemo, but left the choice up to me.  I have pretty much decided to have the chemo because I need to feel that I have done everything possible to give me the best chance.   It's a very personal choice, I have friends and family weighing in with recommendations both ways.  I think I just need to know that I did all I could. The hair thing concerns me too, the oncologist says that I will lose it.  But, I have made stupid choices before because of vanity and I won't let that influence my decision.  Not that it doesn't bother me, but what happens, happens. Chris
Posts.Title: Borderline for Chemo BlueMama Cindy1960

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2008 12:32PM hopefullady wrote: Hello October girls.  I hope you don't mind my popping over from the September 08 board, I wondered how many new girls there were here. I just wanted to say that the tea tree oil is for the fingernails and toenails.  To help with peeling, cracking, coming off the nail bed, etc.  You brush it on the nails.  It isn't for neuropathy.  I think that some girls have recommended taking vitamin B6 for neuropathy.   I don't have any experience with that, at least not yet. Peeps, if you call ahead to the ER or have someone with you to go in first and tell them that you are a cancer patient undergoing chemo, they will put you in a separate place to wait, away from the sick people. Threegirlsmom, I agree that you should probably not take anything before you have the symptoms for it.  I had diarrhea after my treatment and if I had taken a laxative or stool softener ahead of time I hate to think what a mess that would have been.  Certainly do take something as side effects come up, but I wouldn't try to outguess what they will be by medicating ahead of time. Best of luck to all of you who are joining us.  Read the September 08 board to see what we have just gone through and maybe get an idea what to expect.  (((((((hugs))))))) Chris
Posts.Title: Anyone starting chemo in October 08? SuzyWillKickThis unique

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2008 07:02PM hopefullady wrote: I would appreciate any advice, although I know that ultimately I have to make a decision. My tumor was 1 cm, had lumpectomy and mammosite radiation.  I just had the Oncotype test and it came back 20.  My oncologist is recommending chemo and today I had a PET/CT scan and MUGO.   Tomorrow I have labs and another visit with the oncologist.  I have not been able to make a decision.  He said a 13% chance of recurrence with just tamoxifen and with chemo lowered to a 6% chance.  Friends have given their opinions, but of course, they have never been in this situation and the results are about half each way anyway. One day I think that I should have chemo and know that I have done everything possible to improve my odds.  The next day I think that I should not put a fairly healthy body through chemo when they said they got it all, clean margins and no node involvement.   How do you decide what to do?? Chris

Chris
Posts.Title: Mammograms safe or not?? luvz2bmama cp418

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2008 02:44AM hopefullady wrote: Hi Bobbie, I am having focused radiation. Mine is mammosite, and if you google that there is a pretty informative web site explaining it. I had the balloon and catheter inserted on Thursday and a CT scan yesterday to make sure that everything looked good and we could proceed. I will have radiation next week, Monday thru Friday at 8:30 a.m. and 3:30 p.m. each day and then it will be over. I know exactly what you mean. I had kind of a meltdown at the clinic on Thursday. I just didn't know if I could go through even one more procedure just now, I could not bear the thought of another incision, and am so tired of needles and everything. I pulled myself together enough to get it done, and then broke down again after I got home. I have had it easier than a lot of people on these boards, but I still have a little "pity party" now and then. Now, I am dreading having to change my bandages this weekend, but they will do it for me next week, and I am just concentrating on having it over in a week. I know you get really tired of everything, but hang in there. I am tired of being strong too, but I know you can do it and you are certainly not the only one feeling this way. Chris
Posts.Title: focused radiation vs whole brest radiation Marykak Nitsana

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 10:06AM hopefullady wrote: Hi kjbell, I would imagine the onc suggested chemo for you because of the positive nodes.  Chemo frightens all of us, believe me!  The port, if you get one, is really not a big deal.   I just finished my last chemo treatment yesterday, and it is something that you can do if you need to.  There is so much advice and support on these boards and although when you start it seems like it will last forever, it really goes pretty fast.   I would strongly suggest that you get a second opinion to make you more comfortable with your decision.  That's what helped me.   Chris

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2009 11:01PM hopefullady wrote: Hello May 2008 ladies.    I am one of those who has been quietly following your thread for the past year.   I was diagnosed in May 2008, but I was in the September 2008 chemo group.  I have been reading your thread thru my treatment and picked up such wonderful advice and handy tips from all of you.  I learned more about chemo from you women than from my oncologist.  It really helped to read what you had already been through and have some idea what to expect.   Like many of you, I have had to avoid the boards for a while as it's just too painful to read about those starting the journey right now.  I sympathize with them, but I just can't bear to get involved.  Yours is the only thread that I have continued to read.  And, I follow Rock's blog!  Fascinating.  I just wanted you to know that I am so sorry about Randie's passing, and that I feel the pain that you are having.  I know that you will miss her very much.  It is inspiring to me, the love that you all share.  Chris

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2008 03:16PM hopefullady wrote: Harveysjule,   I finished chemo about a month ago.  I am really a wuss when it comes to needles, IVs, doctors, etc., had never had surgery before.  I had the port (still have it), the mammosite, and the chemo.  I found that everything was not as bad as I expected it to be.   Honestly, the anticipation was, in every case, worse than the actual procedure.   I'm not saying any of it was a picnic, but I did it and you can too.  Before you know it, this will be behind you too. Posts.Title: OncotypeDX score, please help! moodyk13 otter

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2008 07:55PM hopefullady wrote: This was one of the hardest decisions I ever had to make.   I would strongly urge all considering it to get a second opinion, as that is what convinced me. I am 51, had a lumpectomy, no node involvement, mammosite radiation.  There was no real reason to believe that any cancer cells were left, but chemo would be a preventive measure. My Oncotype score was 20.  With the lumpectomy, radiation, and tamoxifen for 5 years my doctor said my recurrence rate was 13%.  With that and 4 rounds of TC chemo the recurrence rate would drop to about 6%.    I had my last treatment on November 17.   Chris
Posts.Title: OncotypeDX score, please help! moodyk13 otter

Posts.Content: Oct 10, 2008 10:35AM hopefullady wrote: I had surgery June 2nd and started chemo on September 15th.  It depends on so many factors. I had radiation before chemotherapy.  In my case chemo is an option to prevent recurrence.   Not every case will be the same. Chris
Posts.Title: when does chemo usually start? angel_eyes hopefullady

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2009 11:55PM hopefullady wrote: Stacey, I just wanted to add that they have much improved medicines for nausea now and they will give you some in the drip and also some to take at home.  Take them as directed.  You will be fine.  I finished four treatments of TC in November and I never threw up at all.  You will see that the treatment itself is not nearly as bad as you are anticipating. Brenda is right, we'll be thinking of you in the morning. Chris
Posts.Title: Nervous about starting Chemo 1/2/09 AZStacey2008 AZStacey2008

Posts.Content: Oct 15, 2008 02:06PM hopefullady wrote: As Sue said, it depends on a lot of things.  Do you have reason to think that the cancer is spreading, after a lumpectomy?   Had it spread to the lymph nodes, or been found elsewhere in your body?    I had a lumpectomy the 2nd of June, radiation 3 weeks after that, and started chemotherapy the 15th of September.  But, I had no reason to think that there was any cancer left after the lumpectomy.  The rest of the treatments were preventive measures against recurrence.   I am just guessing that they are waiting for the Oncotype results to determine what further treatments you will need.  Waiting is so very hard.  I'm sure your doctor knows what he/she is doing and that there is not a fast spreading cancer coursing throughout your body. If that were the case you would have had more than a lumpectomy.   I know it's very had to be patient.  There are so many tests, and waiting for results between every one.  Hang in there, we've all been there before and I am sure you will be fine.  You can do it too. Chris
